The  outputs  of  the  Project  will  be  as  follows:  (i)  establishment  of  a 
modern treasury with a nationwide network of treasury offices servicing 
budgetary organizations  of  national  and  subnational  governments  and 
revenue  collection  agencies,  and  development  of  a  functioning 
government  financial  management  information  system  (GFMIS)  to 
facilitate treasury operations; (ii) consolidated and streamlined  treasury 
banking  operations  under  the  established  treasury  single  account 
(TSA); (iii) creation of a central accounting system using a unified chart 
of  accounts  (COA)  in  line  with  the  revised  budget  classification,  the 
International  Monetary  Fund’s  (IMF’s)  Government  Finance  Statistics 
Manual  (GFSM  2001)  and  International  Public  Sector  Accounting 
Standards  (IPSAS); (iv)  a  refined  legal  framework;  and  (v)  application 
of  the  revised  budget  classification  to  the  budget  preparation  and 
execution with improved pilot program budgeting in selected sectors. 
 
The Project will have the following three components: (i) establishment 
of a nationwide institutional network of  treasury offices and support for 
capacity  building;  (ii)  modernization  of  treasury  operations;  and  (iii) 
project management, monitoring, and evaluation. 
 
The first component will provide assistance in establishing a nationwide 
institutional network of treasury offices and associated capacity building 
in  the  areas  where  gaps  are  identified  and  the  needs  are  acute.  In 
particular, the capacity building will include support to build  Ministry of 
Finance  (MOF)  capacity  in  the  maintenance  of  the  GFMIS  and 
management of associated databases.

The TA project will be implemented over a period of 24 months, starting 
in  January  2008. MOF will be the EA for the  TA  project. MOF  Budget 
Department  will  be  the  main  counterpart  for  budget  preparation

individual consultants. 
 
The major benefits of the  Project will be indirect, and will be reflected in 
(i)  improved  budget  quality,  (ii)  budget execution  efficiency  and  linkage 
between budgeting and policy objectives as well as program outcomes, 
(iii) greater transparency and accountability in PFM, underpinned by the 
established  treasury  institutional  network  and  modern  treasury  system; 
and  (iv)  progress  in  the  introduction  of  the  MTBF  and  program 
budgeting.  Direct  economic  benefits  of  the  Project  will be  the  savings 
derived  from  better  cash  management  and  thus  reduced  interest 
payments. 
 
Beneficiaries of the Project will include (i) policy makers  and institutions 
who,  with  the  help  of  the  modern  treasury,  will  be  able  to  make 
decisions  and,  if  necessary,  fiscal  adjustments,  based  on  the  timely 
availability of better-classified information; (ii) stakeholders, including the 
general  public  and  parliament,  who  will  be  able  to  better  assess  and 
monitor  the  effect  of  the  PFM;  and  (iii)  the  general  public,  who  will 
benefit  from  the  provision  of  public  goods  and  services  that  are 
facilitated by improved payment and budget execution processes. 
  
The continued Government commitment to, and ownership of, the PFM 
reform will be crucial for the Project’s success and the achievement of 
the  intended  outcome  and  impact.  This  is  especially  true  when  reform 
in  the  MTBF  and  program  budgeting  becomes  further  advanced.  It  is 
recognized  that  this  is  a  long-term,  complex  task  and  sometimes  an 
iterative  process,  and  will  require  institutional  changes  and  significant 
capacity  building  of  relevant  institutions,  especially  in  formulation  of 
sector policies and development of performance indicators to measure 
and  monitor  the  effect  of  the  reform.  Currently,  the  Government  is 
receiving  assistance  in  this  area  from  United  Nations  Development 
Programme  (UNDP)  and  European  Union  Technical  Assistance  to  the 
Commonwealth  of  Independent  States  (TACIS).  It  is  unclear  to  date 
whether  this  assistance  will  be  adequate,  as  the  needs  may  evolve. 
Consequently  this  will  be  one  of  the  main  areas  for  future  dialogue 
between the Government and ADB. Depending on the country’s needs 
and  the  implementation  of  other  development-partner  programs  in 
capacity  building,  ADB  will  design  its  future  program  in  this  area 
accordingly.

A. 

Performance Indicators and Analysis 

2. 
Uzbekistan is the most populous country in the Central  Asia region and has the second-
largest  economy.  Located  strategically  in  the  center  of  the  region,  it  borders  the  four  other 
Central Asian countries, and  Afghanistan. It is  one of the few “double land-locked” countries in 
the world (i.e., surrounded only by other landlocked countries). Uzbekistan has abundant natural 
resources,  including  gold,  natural  gas,  copper  and  uranium.  It  has  an  economy  dominated  by 
agriculture,  with  almost  70%  of  the  population  living  in  rural  areas.  It  also  has  a  young 
population, with more than 50% of the people under the age of 19.   
 
3. 
At  independence  in  1991,  Uzbekistan  inherited  a  difficult  economic  situation.  The 
economy  then  underwent  significant  changes,  declining  considerably  until  1996 when it began 
to show some modest growth.  Economic growth  has accelerated  during 2004-2006. The gross 
domestic  product  (GDP)  grew  by  7.3%  on  average  during  this  period,  compared  with  4.2% 
during  1999–2003.  Favorable  external  prices  of  Uzbekistan’s  major  exports and real growth of 
noncommodity  exports  have  contributed  to  this  recent  growth.  However,  economic  growth 
remains  narrowly  based  and  the  economy  has  yet  to  realize  its  growth  potential.  Uzbekistan 
remains a low-income country, with per capita GDP estimated at $606 in 2006.  
 
4. 
The economy  experienced significant macroeconomic imbalances until 2000. Since then 
macroeconomic management has improved; monetary policies were tightened and distortions in 
exchange rates reduced, leading to unification of exchange rates and the introduction of current 
account  convertibility  in  October  2003.  However,  the  overall  progress  in  macroeconomic  and 
structural  reforms  has  been  mixed.  There  are  many  daunting  challenges  facing  the  country  in 
carrying out economic reforms, especially in the banking and trade sectors.  
 
5. 
Progress  on the fiscal  reform  has been encouraging.  Lending from the  Central  Bank of 
Uzbekistan  (CBU)  to  the  budget  has  been  discontinued.  Government  expenditure  has  been 
reduced from 45% of GDP in 1998 to about 32% in 2006.  After reaching 10% of GDP in 1998–
1999, fiscal deficits were  subsequently  reduced  significantly  and  have been largely  eliminated 
since 2004. Debt levels have improved with the adoption of prudent fiscal policy and a zero-net-
borrowing strategy. A more detailed sector and subsector analysis is given in Appendix 2. 
  
6. 
After  a  number  of  years of  piloting  various  elements  of  fiscal  reforms,  the  Government 
has adopted a long-term strategic approach to advancing the reform process.  In May 2007, the 
Ministry  of  Finance  (MOF) developed  a  PFM  reform strategy  for  2007–2018 (Appendix 3) with 
support from the  IMF Fiscal  Affairs Department  and  ADB. The strategy outlines an action plan

A  central  element  of  the  PFM  reform  is  to  improve  the  budget  execution  process

provide services to the budget organizations of both national and subnational governments.  It is 
also  planned  to  consolidate  the  currently  fragmented  treasury  banking  operations  under  a 
treasury single account (TSA) at the CBU, to be supported by the computerized GFMIS.

9. 
Key  performance  indicators  to  measure  and monitor  the  progress and  achievement  of 
the  reform  objective  over  the  medium  term  include  (i)  the  existence  of  a  clear annual budget 
calendar,  (ii)  the  requirement  of  appropriation  of  public  expenditure  by  parliament,  (iii)  the 
adoption  of  an  expenditure  commitment  control  scheme  that  can  effectively  limit  the 
commitments  to  actual  cash  availability  to  approved  budget  allocations  for  most  types  of 
expenditure, and (iv) the preparation and regular update of cash flow forecasts on the basis of 
actual cash inflows and outflows.  
  
10. 
Key  performance  indicators  over  the  long  term  include  (i)  linkage  between  budget  and 
policy  objectives  and  programs;  (ii)  budget  preparation  and  allocation  made  with  a  multi-year 
perspective  based  on  reasonable  forecasts  of  major  fiscal  aggregate  for  the next  3 years; (iii) 
inclusion of  cost  implications  in  the  preparation  of  selected  sector  strategies;  and  (iv)  annual 
publication of  an  approved  and  executed  budget  with  a  gradual  increase  in  the  coverage  and 
content, moving toward greater uniformity with international standards and including economic, 
functional, administrative, and program classifications, as well as underlying policy assumptions.

Key Problems 

11. 
Budget  Preparation.  Uzbekistan  inherited  the  budget  preparation  process  that  is 
common  to  all  other  countries  that  were  part  of  the  former  Soviet  Union.  Currently,   budget 
entities prepare their budget requests largely on the basis of previous inputs rather according to 
clear  policies  and  policy  objectives  linked  to  defined  programs  with  performance  indicators. 
MOF receives budget requests from  a large number of budget  agencies,  many of  which lack

Legal  Framework.  The  parliament  approved  the  Budget  System  Law  (BSL)  in 
December 2000, providing a  legal  basis for budget  management. The law sets out the process 
of preparation of the annual budgets by the national and subnational governments. It also lays

A. 

Economic and Financial Analyses 

72. 
The  main  economic  benefits  of  the  Project  are  indirect  and  will  be  reflected  in  (i) 
improved  budget  quality,  (ii)  budget  execution  efficiency and  linkage  between  budgeting  and 
policy  objectives  as  well  as  program  outcomes,  (iii)  greater  transparency  and  accountability  in 
PFM underpinned by the established treasury institutional network and modern treasury system, 
and (iv) progress in the  introduction of the MTBF and program budgeting.  The direct economic 
benefits of the Project are the savings derived from better cash management and thus reduced 
interest payments. 

73. 
The  beneficiaries  of the Project include  (i)  policy  makers  and  institutions  who,  with  the 
help of the modern treasury, will be able to make decisions and, if necessary, fiscal adjustments 
based on  the  timely  availability of  better-classified  information;  (ii)  stakeholders,  including  the 
general public and parliament, who will be able to better assess and monitor the effect of public 
finance management; and (iii) the general public, which will benefit from the provision of public 
goods and services that are facilitated by improved payment and budget execution processes. 
 
B. 

Involuntary Resettlement, Indigenous People, and Environmental Assessment  

74. 
The Project is not expected to  cause direct or indirect involuntary resettlements, nor  will 
it  lead  to  any  issues  affecting  indigenous  people  as  no  project  activities  would  imply 
resettlement  of  people  from  their  traditional  habitations.  It  is  anticipated  that  the  proposed  civil 
works  will  not  trigger  ADB's  Involuntary  Resettlement  Policy.9 Based  on  the  discussions  with 
MOF,  it  was  confirmed  that  all  civil  works related to  the  refurbishment of treasury offices and 
development  of  local  area  networking  will  be  carried  out  in  strict  compliance  with  applicable 
local legislation and will be subject to environmental  monitoring by an authorized environmental 
agency.  Thus,  it  is  anticipated  that  the  Project  is  unlikely  to  have  any  significant  adverse 
environmental impacts. 
 
C. 

Risk Assessment  

75. 
The Government’s continued commitment to, and ownership of, the PFM reform process 
will be  crucial  to  the  Project’s  success,  and  to the  achievement of  the intended  outcome and 
impact. This is  especially  true  with  further  advancement of the reforms in  MTBF  and  program 
budgeting.  It  is  recognized  that  this  is  a  long-term,  complex  task  and  a  sometimes  iterative 
process.  It  will  require  institutional  changes  and  capacity  building  of  relevant  institutions, 
especially  in  formulation  of  sector  policies  and  development  of  performance  indicators  to 
measure and monitor the effect of the reform. Currently the Government is receiving assistance 
in  this  area  from  UNDP  and  TACIS.  As  yet  it  is  unclear  whether  this  assistance  will  be 
adequate, as new needs may evolve. In any case, this will be one of the main areas for future 
dialogue  between  the  Government  and  ADB.  Depending  on  the  country’s  needs  and  the 
implementation  of other development-partner programs in capacity building,  ADB will design its 
future program in this area accordingly.

D.  BUDGET PREPARATION REFORM 

4.1 

Budget Classifications 

The  MOF  plans  to  introduce  new  GFSM  2001-based  budget  classifications  at  the  latest  from 
January 1, 2011, together with the new GFMIS. These new classifications have been designed 
and reflected in the design of the  new GFMIS. The MOF may introduce the new classifications 
earlier than January 1, 2011, on January 1, 2009 or January 1, 2010. 
 
The  GFSM  2001-based  economic  classification  is  planned  to  be  used  for  appropriation 
purposes,  as  is  the  GFSM  2001-based  functional  classification  until  an  independent  program 
classification  is  introduced  after  which  the  functional  classification  is  planned  to  be  used  for 
reporting purposes only. A GFSM 2001-compliant classification of balances and transactions of 
financial assets and liabilities by sector is intended to be introduced for reporting purposes only 
 
A  new  fund  classification  is  also  planned  to  be  introduced,  to  be  used  for  appropriation  and 
control purposes.  
 
The  GFMIS  has  been  designed  to  incorporate  an  independent  program  classification.  It  is 
planned to be activated when program budgeting is fully introduced on January 1, 2011.  
 
These  new  classifications  will  be  necessary  to  fully  realize  the  planned  benefits  from  the 
introduction of the new Treasury.

4.2 

MTBF and Program Budgeting  

A  pre-pilot  MTBF  was  used  by  the  MOF  in  2004,  assisting  it  to  identify  the  consequences  of 
fiscal policy in future years and the impact of new policies on expenditure baselines. The MTBF 
process is planned to be extended in 2008 budget preparation into a full pilot. This is planned to 
be initially predominantly a top-down exercise (the Medium-Term Financial Framework [MTFF]) 
involving the MOF and the Ministry of Economy (MOE) to ensure the sustainability of the annual 
budget,  better  integration  of  capital  and  current  expenditure  budgeting  and  to  derive  financial 
ceilings for annual budget proposals. 
 
It is also planned that line ministries will introduce the MTBF in 2008 budget preparation on the 
basis  of  pilot  programs,  on  a  bottom-up  basis. This  will  build  on  the  pre-pilot, in the MOF and 
selected  line  ministries,  to  give  policy  objectives,  priorities  and  results  greater  emphasis  in 
budget  proposals  and  to  de-emphasize  the  use  of  cost  norms.  It  is  not  intended  to  introduce 
program  budgeting  fully  until  after  the  successful  implementation  of  the  full  pilot  and  with  the 
introduction of the new Treasury system including the GFMIS, currently planned to be January 
1, 2011. 
 
4.3   Appropriation System   

The MOF plans to introduce appropriations of expenditure by the Oliy Majlis, on a cash basis, at 
the  time  the  new  budget  classifications  are  introduced.  It  is  planned  that  appropriation  by  the 
Oliy  Majlis  will  cover  the  republican,  oblast  and  rayon  budgets  as  currently  defined,  plus  the 
budgets of State Targeted Funds (STFs) and the extra-budgetary funds of budget organizations 
(BO-EBFs). The MOF expects that Oliy Majlis appropriation will improve control of expenditure.  
 
It is planned that the appropriation of expenditure by the Oliy Majlis will be at more aggregated 
levels  of  the  classifications,  and  that  these  appropriations  will  be  disaggregated  into  more 
detailed budget allocations approved by the Cabinet of Ministers. 
 
It is not planned to appropriate by programs until program budgeting is implemented fully. The 
application of the appropriation system to STFs and BO-EBFs is planned to be progressive.  
 
4.4 

Inter-governmental Fiscal Relationships 

The MOF plans to develop clearer legal and institutional distinctions between different levels of 
government,  basing  revenue  shares  and  transfers  to  regional  and  local  governments  on  more 
stable and predictable criteria. The MOF expects that this would improve control. The MOF also 
expects  that  the  introduction  of  program  budgeting  will  have  a  significant  impact  on  the 
distribution of policy responsibilities, and hence on the distribution of expenditure responsibilities 
as between central and local government. Accordingly, the MOF plans to commence a review of 
inter-governmental  fiscal  relations  once  the  shape  of  the  future  program  budgeting  system 
becomes clearer. 
 
4.5 

Disclosure of Budget and Financial Information 

Since  the  2003  budget  execution  report,  the  budget  and  budget  execution  reports  have  been 
published on a summary basis.  Over the next decade, planned changes in the structure of the 
budget  and  improvements  in  the  availability  of  budget  and  related  information  will  require 
frequent fresh decisions to be made on the detail of the information to be disclosed to the Oliy

Background 

 
A.  
 
1. 
The Government initiated public finance management (PFM) reform in 2000. Since then 
the  Government  has  undertaken  a  number  of  steps  to  advance  the  reform  process.  One  of 
these  steps  was  the  development  of a PFM reform strategy  for  2007–2018 by  the  Ministry of 
Finance  (MOF)  in  April  2007.  The  strategy  outlines  an action plan  for  the  next  12  years  to  (i) 
establish a functioning treasury system, (ii) adopt and implement a modern unified budget and 
accounting  system,  and  (iii)  introduce  a  medium-term  budget  framework  (MTBF) and program 
budget. 
 
2. 
A central element of the PFM reform is to improve budget execution process significantly 
over the next 5 years. The strategy plans to set up a nationwide network of treasury offices with 
a central treasury in MOF, local treasury departments at regional1 (oblast) level and branches at 
district (rayon) level. These treasury offices will provide services to the  budget organizations of 
both  national  and  subnational  governments.  The  currently  fragmented  treasury  banking 
operations  will  be  consolidated  under  a  treasury  single  account  at  the  Central  Bank  of 
Uzbekistan, supported by a computerized information system. 
 
3. 
Some  of  the  preparatory  work  is  already  underway.  Since  April  2005,  pilot  treasury 
operations  with  limited  but  core  functionalities  have  started  in  Tashkent  city  and  Samarkand 
oblast  and  their  associated  district  treasuries.  These  functionalities  include  procedures  for  ex-
ante checking of  budget organization  expenditures  and  application  of  commitment  controls  by 
preregistration of budget organization contracts. The pilot program extended to six other regions 
by the end of 2006, and there are plans to further cover the whole country. 
  
4. 
MOF  has  done  the  groundwork  for  development  of  an  integrated  IT  system  (the 
government  financial  management  information  system  [GFMIS])  for  use  by  all  treasury branch 
offices and the  central  treasury.  The  GFMIS  will  enhance  the  treasury  functions, substantially 
changing business processes. It will help  to (i) streamline treasury banking and single–account 
operations,  (ii)  release  budget  appropriations  according  to  financial  plans  and  use  cash-flow 
forecasting  to  smooth  payment  financing, and (iii)  create  a  central  accounting  system  using  a 
chart  of  accounts  built  to  reflect  the  revised  budget  classification  in  line  with  the  Government 
Finance  Statistics  Manual  (GFSM  2001)  and  the  International  Public  Sector  Accounting 
Standards  and  off-budget flows.  The GFMIS  will  also  have  a  report  generation  facility  to  meet 
budget  performance  needs  for  in-year  adjustments  and  policy  analysis.  It  will  also  assist 
promotion  of  the  quality  of  annual  budgets  by  its  timely  reporting  on  fiscal  performance,  and 
provide  data  for  checking  validity  of  assumptions,  time -series  comparisons, and trend analysis 
for the medium-term budget framework (MTBF). 
 
5. 
Over the same period, the Government has also undertaken steps to improve the quality 
of  the  budget.  In  2005,  a  medium-term  fiscal  framework  (MTFF)  was  prepared,  establishing 
targets  for  revenues  and  expenditures  for  the  next  3  years  consistent  with  the  medium-term 
projections  of  gross  domestic  product  (GDP).  A  working  group  consisting  of  representatives  of 
MOF,  Ministry  of  Economy  and  the  Central  Bank of  Uzbekistan  developed  projections  of  main 
macroeconomic  parameters,  revenues,  and  expenditures  of  the  state  budget,  and  basic
